H0.text: An increase in the number of bats is the most likely change in the neighborhood caused by a marsh drying up during a long, hot summer.

H1.text: A decrease in the number of mosquitoes is most likely caused by a marsh in your neighborhood drying up during a long, hot summer.

H2.text: An increase in the number of insectâ€‘eating birds is the most likely change in the neighborhood when a marsh in your neighborhood dries up during a long, hot summer.

H3.text: A decrease in the number of Japanese beetles is most likely to result from the marsh in your neighborhood drying up during a long, hot summer.

A4.text: The eggs of most mosquitoes are laid in stagnant water, which may be a pond, a marsh, a temporary puddle, a water-filled hole in a tree, or the water-trapping leaf axils of a bromeliad.

A5.text: Aedes larvae, except when very young, can withstand drying; they go into diapause for several months if their pond dries out.

A6.text: Marshes provide habitats for many kinds of invertebrates, fish, amphibians, waterfowl and aquatic mammals.
